job_title: Server in Batavia, IL
pros: Get to know residents, feel good about caring for others

review_title: Was a great place to work until it wasn’t.
job_title: Receptionist in Carol Stream, IL
pros: Coworkers of the “same level” were very tight knit and came together to provide excellent care and service to residents. We were always there for each other to troubleshoot issues on the weekend when management was absent. Caring for and servicing residents were easily the best part of the job. Actual workplace was also a very beautiful place.
cons: Management cared very little for employee work life balance, asked far more than what was required and took credit/gave no compensation to the employee, never present or set procedures for emergencies. Noticed other coworker’s school schedules not being taken into consideration when scheduling and would tell said employee to find coverage on their class days. Also found that if you weren’t “in” with the clique, they made your experience less than enjoyable from a professional standpoint. Serious harassment complaints were also often brushed under the rug, said “Pray to God and all will be answered in his time.”

job_title: Caregiver, CNA in Spring Valley, CA
pros: Benefits probably the only good thing from this company.
cons: Low pay, for all the responsibilities that Caregivers and CNAs do, we only get the minimum wage. Management is unless, too much gossiping and point fingers at everyone. No happy employees. Rotating days off sucks!

job_title: Line Cook in Keene, NH
pros: flexible schedule, good benefits, friendly residents.
cons: lack of employees, multiple jobs having to be done above just what you were hired for. lack of incentives.

job_title: Resident Assistant in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: I loved the residents but didn't love the toxic environment it was like being back in high school every always gossiped about one another and management played favorites and pay wasn't that great but I did really love the actual job
cons: Pay Work environment The Management

review_title: Hides behind their values to squash growth and dissent
job_title: HR Generalist in Mercer Island, WA
pros: Beautiful campus to work at, nice grounds to walk when you need a break from the gaslighting.
cons: Irresponsible policies around COVID. The business is 100% focused on their residents, which unfortunately for some reason means the employees are not worth valuing and protecting.

job_title: Receptionist in Cromwell, CT
pros: I started working at Covenant Living of Cromwell and I feel like this is the first place I've worked where the cheery administration and flowery declarations of ethical commitment haven't been false. I could mention a lot of things, but I feel that the most telling thing is that I encouraged my grandma to move here after starting to work here and seeing how this community and its staff are truly based on integrity and compassion. She is now a happy resident that has regained some independence and has been more social than she has been able to be in years! This is not my dream career but I will feel confident when I move on that my grandma and all the other residents are truly loved and cared for.
cons: I would like to see more sustainable practices (especially recycling) in the kitchens and around campus, and the communication during the past few years of construction could have been better, e.g. there is currently no specific location for most residents to pick up packages.

review_title: Great people and country-club like environment
job_title: Anonymous Employee in Batavia, IL
pros: Excellent work environment! Interview experience was a breeze. Employees have been very supportive and helpful. Leadership and management is engaged and cares.

job_title: Administration in Tulsa, OK
pros: What I like most about working for Covenant Living is the chance to know that I am helping someone, in this case many someone’s. Each of us gets one shot at this thing called life and most everyone wants, in some way, for their life to count for something. Most jobs do not provide that sense of giving back, helping people in special ways, making a difference in the life of someone. Working for Covenant Living does provide that sense of making a difference with your life. Any job takes up the greatest number of waking hours in your lifetime, why not spend that time making a difference!
cons: weekend work for certain positions

job_title: Receptionist in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: The residents are awesome. They make you feel at home!

Constant turnover in all departments, especially management positions. The job itself was way more than a receptionist position. You’re the first responder to emergencies (resident falls, heart attacks, strokes, etc). There is only a nurse in independent living from 7-3, so after that if anything happens, it’s all on reception.

job_title: Human Resources Director in Santa Barbara, CA
pros: I have worked at The Samarkand for 35 years as the Human Resources Director and I am so proud of all the employees that have worked along side me! i constantly hear from residents "you hire the best employees" and "I just love our staff so much." I have seen employees start in dining service as their first job and then end up nursing, a housekeeper becoming the Director of Housekeeping, and lots of employees create careers for themselves. And when I am downtown, I often run into old employees who greet me with a hug. Samarkand is a great place to work, whether it is your first job in high school, a career choice, or the job you will retire from.
cons: Its hard to lose residents who you have become very close to. however we all know that we provided the best care for them.

review_title: Outstanding place to work and live!
job_title: Resident Services Director in Spring Valley, CA
pros: It’s an honor to be the Resident Services Director at Mount Miguel. I am a people-person and enjoy working in a Christian-based environment that is full of energy, with residents and staff interacting together on a daily basis in an active environment. It’s a pleasure getting to know and develop relationships with the residents. Every day is different, with new challenges and daily rewards. It’s wonderful to be in a position to make a positive difference, however small, in another person’s life. I have this opportunity on a daily basis in my “dream role.” I also LOVE being involved with events, wearing costumes, writing scripts, and creating fun digital programming. Few careers offer so many rewards and I feel blessed to be part of the Mount Miguel family.
cons: I hope the pandemic is behind us soon as our current gatherings are very limited. We are finding creative ways to keep residents engaged during these unprecedented times.

I am thankful for the safety and security that has been given to all of us during the recent pandemic and I honestly feel that next to my home, my job is the safest place I can be! I can't wait to spend the next years as an employee of Covenant Living, it's a great organization!

review_title: Avoid IT Dept. Like the Plague
job_title: IT Department in Skokie, IL
pros: Some genuinely nice people in the organization, especially the older employees.
cons: I left a good paying position to work at this organization.  The CIO was completely dishonest on what  my job responsibilities were and who would be reporting to me.  Expectations were not clearly communicated and feedback was almost non-existent.  Technology was on the low end of adequate and emphasis was on minimizing cost as opposed to providing useful tools for the business.  There was very little discipline in IT dept., one giant lawsuit waiting to happen; juvenile and unprofessional behavior was standard, crude at best and frequently offensive and bush-league.  HR made several serious errors in processing my on-boarding information that would have cost me thousands of dollars had I stayed.  Do yourself a favor, only take a position here if you need to make the mortgage payments.  Keep looking until you can find a good permanent employer.

review_title: Think twice and think very hard before deciding to work for Colorado location

pros: I ABSOLUTELY LOVE THE RESIDENTS HERE. ALSO MOST OF US EMPLOYEES WEATHER WERE IN HOUSEKEEPING, CNA, OR RN'S WE LOOK OUT FOR EACH OTHER AND IF ANYONE NEEDS HELP NO MATTER YOUR TITLE WE HELP!

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Plantation, FL
pros: It's a great thing to be able to say that I get home everyday energized by my job. The employees at Covenant Village of Florida are courteous, attentive to the residents, and generally enjoy working here. It's a positive work environment where you feel supported and valued for the work you do.
cons: It's a big organization, so it takes patience and reasonable expectations when you first work here. Pace yourself with all the learning and you'll soon feel at home.

job_title: Anonymous Employee in Skokie, IL
pros: They believe in growing staff internally, but are not afraid to get an outsider perspective to avoid complacent practices. Go above and beyond to create a special employee/employer relationship that is near impossible to find elsewhere.
cons: Only working 8 hours is sometimes rare, but management is very fair and give fantastic flexibility to counter improve work life balance.

job_title: Registered Nurse in Saint Charles, IL
pros: Facilities were very organized and well run. Patients and families were pleasant. Management and other staff were helpful and friendly.
cons: Computer systems were dysfunctional and tedious; not set up for hospice nursing.  Training was difficult, primarily because the computer system was so terrible for hospice nursing.

job_title: Certified Nursing Assistant CNA in Mercer Island, WA
pros: Compassion for residents/ patients is of high standards.
cons: Too many turn overs in management and CNA's in Health Center. No consistency with rules on co- workers professionalism and attitudes. Too many call ins or no shows to appointed shifts or late shows to shift.

job_title: Resident Aide in Grand Rapids, MI
pros: Flexible schedule for college students!
cons:
I am going to be as honest as possible when writing this review and hope to educate future workers and families of CVGL.. I am very displeased to have to rate the facility as low as a 1 star, but I believe that everyone should know about what this organization stands for and how it operates behind closed doors.

In regards to employment, the staff is constantly stressed out, this extends to aides, CNA’s, cooks, dietary and management. Not only is there a sense of angst and frustration always in the air amongst employees, but also the residents as well. Management often refutes that the residents do not see our stress, however,  they clearly do and they feel it. Since pay is 11.00$ an hour with a max cap at $13.50, employees will often call in. There is no reprimand for calling in, and therefore, the staff is mandated to stay an additional 8 hours (16 hour total) to work. The pay does not compete with any other retirement facility in Kent county. I have done private research through glass door, and indeed (really not that private) with the addition of a few other job sites and have noted that every single nursing facility starts at $13.50 and extends upwards for resident aides. I have noted various locations where weekend pay is 16$ an hour. What I find confusing is that residents pay 6,000$ and up, per month. I am very confused about where that money is going.

Furthermore, I was recently told by a residents family that their mother’s rent went up because the staff was getting a pay increase to their wages as told by management. I contacted management and was told that we would not be receiving a raise. I am concerned that this industry is stealing money from affluent families for their own personal gain. 
Additionally, CVGL does not adhere to hygiene codes and did not have a thorough drug distribution training. This claim is corroborated as resident aides were required to administer food and serve in the dining room after toileting and bathing residents. As a former aide, I constantly took care of urine soaked diapers, BM messes, treating wounds, utilizing needles, passing medications ect. Whilst I also practiced sanitization, that alone, was not a large enough preventive measure for my standards. 
It was disgusting for the residents to know what I had been helping with before lunch, and for myself. I never felt comfortable toileting residents and then serving food right after. Despite aide and resident concerns voiced to management, aides were just released from dietary duty a year after I began working. So, as of now, aides have been out of the kitchen for 2 weeks. When it comes to laundry, don’t assume your getting back clean clothes. While it might have been washed, the soap used as detergent is actually just green hand soap. The clothes never smell clean. This is especially worrisome for those who constantly soil their sheets/clothes.

In regards to passing medication for residents, while there was a training on how to handle drugs, many errors were made in the last year by aides. There needs to be a clear training on what each medication is, as many aides are unfamiliar with drug terminology. This alone, causes great distress to residents as when they ask what pills are what, many staff do not know. This is a direct reflection on management and the lack of training. Furthermore, there needs to be a closer supervision on narcotics as unfortunately these go missing often. 

I am concerned that management will continue taking advantage of families and staff. It is clear that many employees have recognized their worth and quit. While I cared for my former residents deeply, I could not continue to be treated and compensated so poorly. I loved each and every one of my residents like my own grandparent and felt very conflicted about leaving. I obviously am passionate about my residents or I wouldn’t have taken the time to write this comprehensive review.

My objective in this note, is to encourage dialogue about the salary, and treatment of employees at Covenant. I encourage families to demand to know where their money is going and why turnover rates are so high for employees. Almost every corner of CVGL is mediocre at best, however, the staff are the individuals who have the power to make or break this experience with your loved one.
